text: - Hi, I'm Paddy Fitzpatrick. I'm the director for the software sector within AWS for the UK and Ireland.

And welcome to our AWS
for Data YouTube show. I'm really pleased to be
to be joined by Guy Roberts
and Hari Perumal from both from Sophos. So Guy, introduce yourself please.

- Great to be here firstly. So Guy Roberts, I'm the VP of
engineering for Labs platform and that is a part of Sophos X Ops.
- [Paddy] And Hari. - Yeah, thanks for having me first and it's my pleasure to be here. And I'm a senior manager with Sophos Labs

and I manage the building of the content and delivering of the content along with the processing
of the big data teams.

- Ah, excellent. - So part of the Labs platform team. - So for people who don't
understand Sophos and what you do,

could you tell us a little bit more about- - Sophos is a global
leader in cybersecurity. It was founded in 1985. Can you believe?

Way back when cybersecurity
was called antivirus and founded in Oxford.

That's what we do. So we sell cybersecurity
products and services. - And you mentioned X Ops,

I can't start without
understanding, what is X Ops? - So X Ops, I like to think
of the kind of core of Sophos,

we create all the secret source that goes into Sophos is
products and services. So we create all the threat
intelligence and the detections
and the protection that kind of drive all of the products within Sophos. - Okay, great, thank you.

So tell me a bit more
about the Sophos products and how they've evolved.

- Well, way back when, it was
all about the end products that go into the various different places
where the customers need them. So over the years we focused on that. We now have what we call

a suite of next generation products. So we have the Intercept
X flagship product

that runs on the endpoints, and then we have a range of
products with the XG branding

that are the firewalls
and a few in between. Now we have a centralized console

where you can manage
those in a unified way. And we call those
products next generation.

So that means that they have
AI and ML engines in there, they have behavioral aspects to them

and they are kind of
tightly cooped to the cloud. So that's the product range as it is.
And then recently we've added detection and response capabilities. So this allows our customers

to understand their risk profile and sort of see incursions
from the bad guys
and respond to that. So that's the EDR capabilities that you'll hear about in the industry

and of in the last couple of years. The last piece on that, so I mentioned the service layer
is we want to add a service

or we have added a service
offering on top of that. So that's where we
manage for our customers. We manage that response
using the tools that we have.

That's the MDR service
that we've layered on top. That's how we've evolved over time. - So EDR is?

- Endpoint detection and response and then MDR is managed
detection and response. That's where we take those tools

and we actually manage
them for you as a service, much like AWS manages your infrastructure

rather than you investing your time looking after your own data center. So very, very similar
to that in some sense.

- Got it. Great. And are you seeing customers want to have that management of it rather than have them
having to run it themselves?

- Yeah, I think with
the increasing diversity of threats out there,

in particular with GenAI coming up, just keeping up to speed with what you need to do it is just becoming more
and more complicated

and we're now at a point really where most customers
can't effectively keep up and can't effectively
manage their own estate.

So they really do need
a service like this. So, which is why we're
focusing on it. Yeah.

- Okay, great. So you mentioned
GenAI or generative AI.

So I mean it's quite evident now that organizations are
having massive culture change
as they think about generative AI. How does Sophos think about generative AI?

- Well, the first thing to
say I think is certainly AI, is not new to us.

So we've been using AI, machine
learning in the industry, cybersecurity industry
and in Sophos too for,

I guess it goes back to the
days of Bayesian analysis in spam 20 odd years ago.

And iterations of that
through those years. I suppose the next milestone
for Sophos was 2016

when we acquired Invincea and that brought in the deep learning kind of new network level
of sophistication for ML

and we now have that type of model. We have dozens of instances
of that type of technology running in production all the time,

have done for a number of years. So it's not new, but I think
GenAI is a new chapter.
It is different. And so yeah, we're starting to embrace it. - Yeah, as you say,

we've been working together for years on artificial intelligence,
machine learning, but GenAI seems like it is a new chapter.

Do you wanna expand on how
that's changed your thinking? - Yeah, so certainly I
think the way that we see AI

in Sophos is really those two buckets. So you have the smaller,
more focused ML models

and if you think about their input, normally it's some threat
object, it's some feature vector

and their output is
deterministic and it's a verdict. So it is not very verbose

and that's what we have
embedded in our systems. GenAI is very different. So the input is human language, really,
the output is non-deterministic. So you don't always get the same output each time you run it.

And I think one key difference is, with those smaller and
more targeted models, we've incorporated them to a point now
where they can largely run with a few kind of guardrails on their own and provide value on their own.

With GenAI at the moment
we're not at that point, they really are kind of co-pilots. They are there to aid and
help ultimately a human.
So that's the kind of differences in the two types that that we see. - Okay.
And can you gimme some specific use cases for generative AI? - In cybersecurity? Yeah, I suppose there's really,

there's really a couple
of buckets of those. So it's what it means
for the threat landscape and what the bad guys
are doing with GenAI.

Then there is obviously
what we're doing with GenAI, the good guys.

And then in particular Sophos, we have a particular use case, which is how we grow
our services business,

our MDR business in a
kind of non-linear way. So those are the three
buckets of use cases

that I like to think about
generally for Sophos. - And specifically, if you are specific about a certain case,
then the cybersecurity as a service. We have about 23,000 customers,

but when this business grows we cannot be growing the
teams to support that. So we need GenAI models to be there
to create those playbooks to rapid protection for our customers.
So that's important for us. - Oh, that makes sense, yeah. Allows you to scale through technology. So you mentioned, Guy,

about cyber criminals using generative AI and it strikes me that we
hear a lot about people

rushing towards wanting to use it, but it also becomes quite a
powerful tool for bad actors.

- Yep. In certain ways. The bad guys, any
technology for that matter

is used by both good and bad. And GenAI doesn't be seem to
be the different one there.

So it could land in
the hands of bad actors where they can become more
sophisticated in their attack

so they can become faster
in their campaigns. So specifically if
you're quoting an example
being phishing emails, so they want to do a campaign and they can do it much faster, much more authentic text on those emails
for them to capture their attention. The other one is, they can develop malware tooling on that,
so they see some vulnerability and they can fastly develop a tool
to spread them malware on that. So that's another case where the bad guys can get into using the GenAI.

- So I'm right, I'm thinking that it
lowers the barrier to entry for want to be sophisticated. - Yeah, it does that, I
agree, I agree with Hari.
I think the primary actual usage is making them more efficient with the types of attacks
that they've been doing in the past. Plus it lowers the to entry for new people

who wanna do this type of thing. That's really where it's
changing most things. There are some particular threat vectors

related to the actual technology, with jailbreaking AIs and
getting them to do things,

but really they're at the
proof of concept stage, there's not really that
much activity around them.

So at the moment really, it's just that efficiency boost that the bad guys are getting
and the barrier to entry

that we're all kinda seeing. So I think that's where the
biggest boost is at the moment. - And how have you responded
within Sophos Labs?

- Well, I suppose we've certainly
developed sort of features to help our customers

understand how their users are accessing some of this technology. So we have web filtering, so that's one approach on
the product side of things,

we certainly use, I suppose there's two ways that
we use it as the good guys.

So again, a lot of it is around automation and being more efficient about
the approaches that we take.

Remember these things are always co-pilot, so they're helping our analysts and it's actually quite
good timing for us.

'Cause if you think about
the kind of alert fatigue, the volume of information
that keeps coming our way,

and you think about the classes
of data in cybersecurity, so you really have the
threat objects themselves,
spam emails, web pages, files, and you have the detections themselves.

Both those two things either
are text-based, language-based, or you can generate reports about them
that are text-based and language-based, which makes them really, really amenable to some of these technologies.

So given that, we can use all the types of
things that off the shelf, things that you would expect from GenAI
because the nature of these things is that they are tech space. So we're using all of it,

the semantic search, the
vector dbs, the rag things and all the automation
that comes with that

to make us more efficient and
more accurate in response.

So Hari, do you got
anything to add to that? - I think you pretty much covered it. There are specific use cases
where we look at the data

and then the researchers have come up with a certain playbook,
okay, they see this, this,

then we can call the customers and tell them, "Okay,
you are under attack." Those kind of things can be
done much easily with GenAI.
- So there's the speed of that. - Yeah, the speed of that. - When I speak to customers around about artificial intelligence
and especially generative AI, we have conversations around what they need to do culturally.
And so how do they build a culture where people understand prompt engineering
or are more confident to look for AI

and how it can help them do their jobs or serve their customers. But it strikes me that
also within the culture

of using GenAI, there's a security culture that needs to be evolved
around it as well.
So what are your thoughts on that? - Well certainly I would say with GenAI,

I think obviously it's
garbage in, garbage out. So a lot of it is about getting
the upstream data, right?

And we saw this with early
iterations with of AI too. With the deep learning,

it's great to have the
mathematics, the algorithms, but unless you get the data right,

it's not that good. And so a lot of effort
that we saw back then,

getting that stuff to
market is also true here. So I think really, you need to be thinking
about your data quality
and your data hygiene upstream to get the best that you can out of AI.

That's one key thing. I think the other thing
I think with AI is,

there is a hype cycle and you need to be getting
the balance right with that.

So I think all of us are
exploring and learning and given the nature of what it is,

you've got to explore and learn. But I think when you pull
things towards production,

you've got to have them
kind of underscored with good old fashioned business metrics

and kind of walking the
balance between the two I think is key. So yeah. Hari what?

- Yeah, to add to that, when we have this garbage
in, as Guy mentioned,

garbage in, garbage out, the quality of data that
goes into the AI systems is very critical
and what goes in shouldn't be poisoned. So we need to take care of that as well.

So the integrity of those
generative AI systems is very, very critical for us.
- Yeah, I've heard people talking about, going slow to go fast. So getting the data
and the data integrity right first, before even looking at generative AI model

or training models. So I guess you'd agree with that? - Absolutely, yeah. - So there quite a lot of
different types of data

that we get, but the quality of the data that goes through the
researchers analysis first,

that's very important. So that's the very
highest quality of data. And then we have mission analysis

of data that's coming through and then the feed that
we get from the industry.

So that helps us to produce a good model that will be useful for
protecting our customers.
So that's where it stands out. - And to what degree do we think,

as we sort of wrap up on GenAI, to what degree do you
think it is a hype cycle or what are your thoughts around that?

- Well, I mean, I think you've gotta, for sure some of it is hype,
but you've gotta explore

and find the right places
where it's gonna work. And without doubt, you've gotta do that. And I think the people that
do that in a kind of subdued,
kinda behind the scenes metric driven way, whilst that won't grab the headlines, I think it'll be those people,

or those companies or those organizations that actually win in the
long term with this stuff.

- So data quality is critical for the
effectiveness of product insights

to any consumer. But what strategies does
your organization employ to gather and maintain high quality data?

- Hari, do you wanna say this? - Yeah, so what we do is, we have our edge servers
running on all over the world.

So when the data comes into
each of our edge servers, what we collect them

and make sure they're processed correctly so that they might contain
the PA information.

So before they leave that region, we ensure that the data is
removed of any PA information
and they contain both PA information and the threat related information. So for our research,

we are interested only in the
threat related information. So when the products are being developed,

they work with the legal teams to put the right data in the right place so that it is easy to strip
off those PA information

and take only the valuable
threat information for our further analysis. So that's very important for us.

And once we have that into our systems where it can be processed, then it is matter of us
giving it in the right format

for the researchers to look at it. - So I mean, what Hari
said it right there, I think we're quite lucky in
the cybersecurity industry,
probably not the same in other places, but the data that we are interested in

is about the threats themselves, the threat information
that's within the artifacts.

And that is very often very different than the data that is
private to the customer. And so our job is to split the two.

And if we do that well, which we need to do, then actually, we're in a kind of philosophically
aligned place with that.

- And just, I know we've spoken before about the volume of data
that Sophos manages.

Give us an idea for the
sort of scale of data and- - I'll do my bit and Hari can add.

So we have Hari's talked
about the edge services. So we have edge services that respond to the Sophos products out there.

We do billions of queries, well we do billions of queries
an hour responding to those.

So giving answers to the products and that drives a huge amount of data, which is the data that we
then process in the back end

and Hari, hopefully you
got a number on there. - Yeah. So we have about 6.2 million
endpoints running the product.

So when they send back, we are able process about 60
terabytes of data in a day.

And to manage this, we cannot take everything
and be processing it. So we need to ensure that
we look at the signals

and leave out the noise. So that's where signal to noise processing comes into picture when we are dealing with
the big data volume.

- Okay, so I mean there's
big numbers of billions and so when you talk,
sort say signal to noise,

just expand on that for me please. - So we get a lot of
telemetry from our end points.

So it is critical that we
get clean, we get unknowns, we get certain definite detections.

So it is important for our researchers to know what they need to see. So the use case comes
from the researchers.

They're saying, "Okay,
this is the type of data that they would like to see." And when we are able to filter
out what is not required,

so that's the filtering out of the signal. And leaving out the noise. So that's the signal to
noise that I'm talking about.
- And most people who even watch this won't be dealing with billions of,

processing billions of
pieces of data every hour. So how do you then think about data,
data quality, tiering that sort of thing? What's your advice to people?

- Well, I think it is, so the signal to noise
things, I think it's important because if you throw away the noise, then you are reducing
the risk of that noise,
having some private data in it. So just focus on what you need, for us that threat information, that's the signal to noise piece.

I think it's important
to have clear boundaries between classes of data.

So we have data upstream that we keep as close to
the customer as we can, and then we have definitive boundaries.

And when we have a new data type cross one of those boundaries, that's a trigger moment for going through that
discussing with legal.
So it's having those clear boundaries between the different data domains

and we set that up, that
kind of way of thinking, that philosophy, that framework
around the time of GDPR

and it served us pretty well. So having those clear
boundaries I think is important.

- And I think, Hari, you
mentioned PII and guide GDPR. So a lot of,

you need to protect
customer data, don't you? And there's a lot of considerations around the rules and
regulations around that as well.
- For sure. Yeah. - Okay, so good. How do you handle the ethical concerns

related to data privacy and
consent in different regions? - So it's really critical for us

to be ethical about what we are handling. So that's where the PA
filtering comes into picture.
So we cannot store data more than what it is required for. So our legal teams are very strict

on how long we store the data,
what kind of data we store, and where it is stored, how it is stored,

all those kind of things
comes into picture. So when a customer is, the
endpoints are sending the data,

we make sure, when they're
crossing the boundaries, those data is again, PA filtered
and only the threat related data is taken into our research systems.
So that's where we are very specific about how we handle the data. So when we look at the data from our end,

after it is being processed, it is not possible to
find where it came from, our individual users, where it came from.

So to that level, we
can anonymize the data. - Excellent and over and above

some processes and technology. I think when we were
talking about generative AI, we touched on culture.
So when we think about data strategy, how do you think about culture and how do you develop the right culture

when people think about data? - Yeah, I mean this is a
fascinating topic really. And it's hard work to get the
right type of data culture,

culture to develop your
data strategy really. And I think there's a couple
of reasons why that is.

One, I think is the good old, people see organizations
in the human hierarchies,

and that's how humans
have evolved to work. But that's not necessarily
a great way to run

or to house a data strategy. So you've got to think of
ways of kind of changing that,

you can't really run it
in a hierarchical way. So really it's those good old principles

that come up with Agile
development, for example. You need to get teams to be empowered

and owning their decisions end to end. You need to do that within
guardrails and guidelines,
but you need to sort of step back and allow them to be empowered. That's important, I think.
You also need to make sure that teams own that delivery end to end,

and that when a team is developing a new
feature or a new product, that the data output is an
important part of that product

or a data product and the team doing the
feature needs to own that.
I think that is key. I think you also need to,

you need to really grow the
disciplines within data science. So data engineer, data analysts,

all those different disciplines, you need to grow and nurture
those as individual disciplines

and give them pedigree
and give them the support. But you don't wanna silo those. You need to have those skill sets

and those disciplines within
those individual teams.

So you want to have teams that are made up of those
different disciplines and software developers and DevOps people,

but you certainly need
to nurture those things. So there's some of the things,

I think some of the other things that I'm sure other companies
would have challenges with,
that Sophos has. Sophos is built from, it's cybersecurity.
So the people that are in the company, they've come to the company because they are cybersecurity experts,

they're not data experts. And I think somebody recently said, "Every company these
days is a data company."

I wouldn't entirely say that, but I can sort of see
where they're coming. And so you've gotta
take these professionals

and you've got to get
them to understand data and you've got to get them to embrace it

and start kind of showing them how it can lead the way in
their particular profession.
And I think that that's a journey also that we've been on. So yeah, a few things there.

It is difficult and it's
not easy to get right, but I think that there's
some pointers there.
- So we're really interesting there about the culture of those teams. And it feels, as you say there,

it breaks away from the
traditional hierarchy. And it makes me think again of,

Amazon and how we would
have two piece of teams cross-functional teams, small teams that can manage
a product end to end.

And it's almost quite organic
in nature, in that sense. - I had two pieces teams on
the tip of my tongue there,

but it didn't quite, I didn't, yeah, I held it back by, but exactly. - Oh, I'm the ones who bring
the Amazon flavor to it.
Excellent. And also I guess it's important not to be fixated on the tool-

- I think that's a really important one. I think it's so, it
happens quite a lot is, people spend a lot of time
deciding which is the best tool.
And of course getting the right tool is an important part of it, but it's not all of it.

I think really you need
to focus on the job and how you approach the job.
And in many sense, as long as you've got a reasonable tool, you will get the job done.

I think what happens if
you focus on the tool is that you land up thrashing, you land up migrating from
one tool to the other,

and you land up focusing
on what the tool can do and comparing it. Meanwhile you are not getting
on with the underlying job.

And I think that is an
understandable distraction sometimes that that organizations have on the tool.

- To add to that, there are companies which have
solved the existing problems, what you're facing, the others
would've already solved it.

Look at how they have solved it and then it's easy for you
to, what's your use case?

Can you use that solution for yourself? So going in that line will help, and not randomly going
around, but making sure

that you are following
the right method to do it. So that's important there.

- Makes a lot of sense. So every turn to processes
that are driven by data, how do you ensure that
data-driven insights
make their way into product development and to the products and services that you offer to your clients?
- How do we make our projects and products are data driven?

I would say a couple of ways. So one is we obviously have a process, like everybody else has, for ideation through
delivery and project set up.

And we ensure that there
are success criteria that are related to data observables.

So metrics. So that's one thing, everybody should be doing
that to some degree.
I think the other one is making sure that data is an output,
not just a measurement of success, but an output of the product.
So those are a couple of things in terms of actually delivering projects in a kind of data thoughtful way.

- And do you have an example
of where a data-driven insight has changed the development of a project,

of a product or the outcome of a project? - Yes, so we have something
called the early warning system.

So, which is purely driven by data. We have lot of thread data available and when the researchers
look at it, they can say,
"Okay, this particular thing, our particular customer is under attack." So they can want the customer early.

So when we develop that and it became a driver
for the managed detection
and response teams. So that's a business that we diverted into from the early warning system.
So that's a very specific example of how the data is driving our business.

- Yeah, excellent. And what about user interfaces
or things like that I guess-
- Yeah, so this is an interesting one. So internally within my team, our users,

our internal researchers and analysts, they are notoriously difficult
to get requirements from.
I could completely understand why, they're focused on the coalface. They're dealing with the next outbreak or the next ransomware attack.

And so we obviously work very
hard to see what they need. And we do that, of course we do,
but also we get telemetry from our tools so we can see which tools they're using
and which tools they're not. And that the ones that are not is actually equally important.

And that tells us where we can focus, sounds simple, but actually
it's very effective.
- Excellent. So how do you prioritize which data points are most important to focus on

and how does this
influence product roadmaps? - We do, I mean, I suppose there's a couple of areas we do.

We do try and use the data to infer a sense of ROI
in terms of metrics.

So we do that. So we have success
criteria for our projects
and we have a sense of ROI with them, but I do think you need to blend that with good old fashioned experience as well

and have a kind of combination
of those two things. So that's what we tend to do. Yeah. - So the tech landscape is,

it's brimming with technology
products and choices, and people have to navigate through that.

So can you gimme some insight into how you've made
some technology decisions in terms of what technologies
you've decided to use?

- Certainly, I mean we've
certainly been on a journey in the last decade or so. And I've been at Salesforce
for 10 years now.
When we started at Salesforce, we were managing all of our infrastructure in our own data centers.

We had a massive Hadoop cluster I believe, that we used to drive
all our insights from,

and we looked after that. So we've come a long way from that. We're now 90% there or
thereabouts in the cloud.

And along that path,
on the big data front, we've made a few decisions.

And Hari, I'm sure you can share those. - So like any technology
there is limitation.

So with the data center, we had limitation of how much of telemetry that we can process,
how much we can store.
So that's when we decided, "okay, we need something bigger for it." So we looked at S3 as a data lake
and when we took on S3 and then Redshift as our data warehouse,

so we were able to process
much more efficiently and store much larger data

and for a longer period of time so that the researchers
can have a look at it. And not only that,

our edge servers are also
supported by the DynamoDB for their reputation and other things.
And we are also looking at the OpenSearch, which the researchers love it

because it gives us
them the faster response and we can ingest the data much faster
and much more easy to query. So that's where the OpenSearch stands. - [Paddy] Okay, so-

- You're looking at semantic
search and everything else. - Okay. So you're using OpenSearch and DynamoDB,
Amazon Redshift and S3. Excellent. So what about the road ahead?

What's in the future for Sophos? - Well, I'm not sure
in terms of technology, but what I do think is pretty interesting
in this whole space is that at Sophos, we've invested in pretty heavily
in this type of infrastructure. And we have a lot of data coming in.
We have a lot of data that's there already and we have streams of data coming in. And what's interesting now

with GenAI on these new
techniques that are coming up is we can take those and apply them to our existing
infrastructure and data
and I'm quite excited to see what value, latent value we can extract from that.

So that's where I'm
excited about the future. - Hari, what are your views?
- So yes, what Guy was saying is, where we look at the data

and it's critical that
we build some playbooks so that we can respond to
our customers much faster.

Currently using GenAI, we can do that, the early warning system that
I spoke about was an example,
but we can be much faster in delivering, using the GenAI technologies.

- And I know that you've
had the opportunity to work with the AWS service teams

to look at different technologies
and new technologies. What value do you get out of that access

with the service teams where
you can go and dive deep? - Well, I think it's true to
say that the pace of change,
even going back to the cloud revolution, and then big data and then GenAI,

it's fast and it's hard to keep up, especially when you are focusing
on your own domain area,

your domain expertise,
your day job really. And there is a gap. There's a gap between what we can do
and what we can take advantage of. And I think the great job that AWS does

and our account teams
and the support teams is help us fill that gap
or at least close it.

I don't think we think
we'll ever close it. But with that support
we can at least close it and that's what I'm yeah, so thankful for.

- Yeah, and I know you
push us quite hard as well- - [Guy] Absolutely, absolutely. - So embedded in technology yourself.

So when we think about cybersecurity and how that's going
to continue to evolve,

has Sophos positioned to solve the toughest challenges of it? - I mean, I think it comes
down to the pace of change

accelerated by GenAI, as
we talked about earlier on, the bad guys will get familiar with this,
it'll become commoditized. They will start upping their game. The barrier to entry is lower for them,

so it will get more fast and furious. The bad guys will get more
prolific and more sophisticated

and that's gonna make
it harder, even harder for your typical organization
to keep pace with it all.

And I think that's gonna mean that people are gonna increasingly
want to look at some help,

look at services to help them
manage their risk profile. And obviously Sophos is in
a great position with that

because we have that
service offering already that's in place to offer that.

So I think there'll be
increasing interest in that, plus all the investment
